Albania: Corfu Channel Incident: United Nations Security Council Resolution 22 recommended that the International Court of Justice settle the dispute between the UK and Albania regarding the sinking of two British ships in the Straits of Corfu. The Economic Planning Commission first drew up an economic plan with production targets for mining, manufacturing and agricultural enterprises. Greek Civil War: A United Nations commission concluded that Albania, together with Bulgaria and Yugoslavia, supported Communist guerrillas. Yugoslavian leaders launched a verbal offensive against anti-Yugoslavian Albanian Communists, including Hoxha, empowering the pro-Yugoslavian faction. Albania refused to participate in the Marshall Plan of the United States.
Bangladesh: Partition of British India, Pakistan and India become two independent states.
Bhutan: The British Empire leaves India, and direct political by the British ends. Bhutan remains relatively isolated from international affairs.
Brazil:
Parliamentary elections are held, for 19 vacant seats in the Chamber of Deputies, one additional Senator for each state (except Santa Catarina, which elected two), and for all state Governors and legislatures   The Brazilian Communist Party wins nearly 10% of the vote in the state elections, becoming the third party in the state of São Paulo (ahead of the UDN) and the single largest party in the federal capital, Rio de Janeiro.
The Brazilian Socialist Party is founded.
The São Paulo Museum of Art opens to the public.
Burma:
Panglong Agreement signed by Shan, Kachin, Chin and Burman leaders to gain independence from the British
Aung San and most of his cabinet assassinated. U Nu and his AFPFL party prepare to take power from the British by finishing Burma's first constitution
1947 Constitution guarantees the Federated Shan States (later Shan and Kayah states), Kachin State, and Karen State, the right to secede after a period of ten years after independence
China: February 28 Incident: Nationalist forces violently suppressed an anti-government protest in Taiwan Province. The Constitution of the Republic of China came into force, dissolving the Nationalist government and renaming the NRA the Republic of China (ROC) Armed Forces.
France: Vincent Auriol began his term as the first president of the Fourth Republic.
India:
Indian Independence Act 1947 by British Raj
Partition of India and Pakistan becomes an independent state on 14 August 1947.
Freedom from British Raj.
Hundreds of thousands die in widespread communal bloodshed after partition, continuing to 1948.
Indinesia:
Linggadjati Agreement, first ceasefire.
Major Dutch military offensive to resolve differences by force.
Italy: Primo Levi publishes If This Is a Man, based on his experiences in Auschwitz.
Japan: The Constitution of Japan goes into effect. This changed the Empire of Japan into the State of Japan (Nihon Koku, 日本国) with a liberal democracy. Article 9 turned Japan into a pacifist country without a military.
Malta:
Restoration of Self-Government.
Malta receives £30 million to assist with post-War reconstruction.
Nepal: Nepali National Congress established through merger of former All-India Nepali National Congress with Nepalese Society of Banaras and Gorkha Congress of Calcutta
Philippine:
Rehabilitation Finance Corporation (RFC), later Development Bank of the Philippines, begins its operations.
President Roxas issues an amnesty proclamation to collaborators
An amendment in the 1935 Constitution granting parity rights to the Americans is ratified in a plebiscite.
The Military Assistance Act is signed by U.S. Ambassador Paul McNutt and Pres. Roxas.
HUKBALAHAP declared illegal
The Treaty of General Relations between Philippines and United States, the Military Bases Agreement, is signed; would be effective until 1991.
The Philippine representative to the Far Eastern Commission, Carlos P. Romulo, signs the Japanese Peace Treaty
Corregidor Island in Cavite is turned over to the Philippines.
Turtle Islands, now in Tawi-Tawi, is placed under country's jurisdiction.
First post-war elections held for local officials and senators.
Poland:
Legislative election rigged, 100,000 ORMO men deployed to intimidate voters
Adoption of Small Constitution of 1947
Operation Vistula begins
Auschwitz trial begins in Kraków
Russia: 1947 Polish legislative election: Rigged elections gave the Communist bloc 80 percent of the vote. The Hungarian Communist Party won a plurality of seats in elections to the Hungarian legislature. The Cominform was established in order to coordinate Communist parties under Soviet control. A speech to the Central Committee of the KSČ by Chairman Klement Gottwald denounced "reactionary forces" and triggered the purge of non-Communists from the Czechoslovakian security forces. King Michael I of Romania was forced to abdicate.
Singapore:
A large number of strikes occur causing stoppages in public transport, public services and the harbour.
Severe food shortage leads to record-low rice ration, causing malnutrition, disease and outbreak of crime and violence.
Slovenia: 21 countries sign the Paris peace conference with Italy. Free Territory of Trieste (STO – Svobodno tržaško ozemlje) is established in Ljubljana.
Sweden: Furniture company, IKEA, founded by Ingvar Kamprad
Syria: The first Ba'ath Party congress was held in Damascus.
Taiwan: Taipei's rice market closes due to a riot February 28 Incident: Six officers attempt to arrest a woman selling cigarettes illegally in Taipei, a Taiwanese man is killed, and as a result mass riots break out all over the island February 28 Incident: Reinforcements from mainland China arrive in Keelung February 28 Incident: The Taiwanese resistance is defeated by KMT Chen Yi is replaced by Wei Daoming
